snippet.title: Cricket Australia and players sign peace deal to end pay war
snippet.content: Australian cricket's long and ugly pay dispute is finally over, with Cricket Australia and the players finally agreeing on a peace deal on Thursday afternoon. After 10 months of butting heads, the sports' worst industrial crisis in 40 years had accelerated towards a resolution following a threat last week by CA chief executive James Sutherland to have the matter ruled upon by independent arbitration. Photo: Daniel Pockett The negotiating teams from CA and the Australian Cricketers' Association had worked long in the night throughout this week to settle their remaining differences in the drafting of a heads of agreement, as the troubled talks threatened to go off course again. They were at last able to find middle ground on Thursday. An announcement in a media conference is expected this afternoon at 4:30pm in Melbourne. The long-awaited deal on the game's next five-year memorandum of understanding between the governing body and players arrives just in the nick of time to save this month's two-Test series between Australia and Bangladesh. It also ensures that this summer's Ashes series in Australia will go ahead, as will an Australian limited-overs tour of India in October. Steve Smith's squad is due to assemble in Darwin for a training camp next week before taking off to the subcontinent for a series that they were refusing to play in had there not been a new MOU agreed.
